Description: Mould-made lamp with red slip. This is a red clay oil lamp of frog lamp shape with a slightly raised circular base, and a body leading out to a nozzle. It has no handle. The centre of the body is pierce with a circular hole, surrounded by a raised rim. Traces of a slip exhibiting the same colour variation(s) as the fabric. Secondarily (?) mottled to grey/black on underside. Well levigated Delta silt. Fine (sand-size to 1 mm) white and dark grey grit temper with some micaceous inclusions of similar size. Fabric c. 5YR 6/3 (Light Reddish Brown) to 5/3 (Reddish Brown) with a core ranging from grey, through 10R 5/8 (Red) to 5YR 4/6 (Yellowish Red).
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Great Temenos, South Mound 49149 N.I.491.64 Phase NW8A
Curator's comments: Complete parallel from Naukratis (Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H2762). 'Hellenistic type' (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q593, Q595). Parallels dated late late 2nd to early 1st century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, 62, Type J, Fig. 87). However, similar form dated Late 3rd to 2nd century BC was found at Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.4). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould- made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton.
Bibliographic references: Leonard 1997 / Ancient Naukratis: Excavations at a Greek Emporion in Egypt, Part I: The excavations at Kom Ge’if. (pl. 7.6 ; pg. 290)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.035) (Phase 3)
